title: The Burden of Babylon
shortSummary: Isaiah 13 pronounces a prophetic oracle against Babylon, foretelling its destruction as an act of divine judgment. The chapter vividly describes the coming day of the Lord, marked by wrath, cosmic disturbances, and the overthrow of a proud and oppressive empire. This prophecy serves as a solemn warning of God's sovereignty over nations and His righteous judgment against sin.
timeline: c. 740-700 BC - Isaiah's prophetic ministry during the Assyrian and early Babylonian ascendancy

keyCharacters.name: Isaiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet and son of Amoz who receives and delivers God's message concerning Babylon's judgment.

keyCharacters.name: The Medes
keyCharacters.description: A people stirred up by God to execute judgment against Babylon, noted for their fierce and merciless conquest.

keyCharacters.name: Babylon
keyCharacters.description: The great city and empire prophesied to face destruction due to its pride and sinfulness.

definitions.definition: A prophetic oracle or message of judgment, often heavy and serious in nature.
A future time when God will intervene decisively in history to judge sin and establish His kingdom.
Those set apart by God for a special purpose, here referring to His mighty warriors or angels executing judgment.
A reference to extremely valuable gold from Ophir, symbolizing great worth and preciousness.
Mythical creatures often associated with desolation and wilderness, symbolizing the utter ruin of Babylon.

outline.heading: Introduction and Call to Prepare for Battle
outline.description: Isaiah introduces the burden against Babylon and calls for a banner to be raised as a signal for God's appointed warriors to assemble for judgment. This section emphasizes God's sovereign command over the nations and the gathering of His forces.

outline.heading: The Terror of the Day of the LORD
outline.description: A vivid description of the coming day of the Lord characterized by fear, cosmic disturbances, and divine wrath. The passage highlights the universal scope of God's judgment and the humbling of the proud.

outline.heading: The Flight and Destruction of Babylon
outline.description: Depicts the panic and slaughter that will overtake Babylon’s inhabitants, including the merciless actions of the Medes. This section underscores the certainty and severity of Babylon’s downfall.

outline.heading: The Complete Desolation of Babylon
outline.description: The final judgment results in Babylon becoming an uninhabited wasteland, likened to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah. The imagery of wild beasts and desolation symbolizes total abandonment and divine wrath.

application: Trust in God's sovereign control over nations and history, knowing He will bring justice in His perfect timing.
Recognize the seriousness of pride and sin, which provoke God's righteous judgment.
Live in readiness for the day of the Lord by repenting and seeking holiness, avoiding the fate of Babylon.
Pray for God's justice to prevail and for His mercy to be extended to those who turn to Him.

keyVerses.text: Howl ye; for the day of the LORD is at hand; it shall come as a destruction from the Almighty.
keyVerses.significance: This verse powerfully announces the imminent and unstoppable nature of God's judgment.

keyVerses.text: And I will punish the world for their evil, and the wicked for their iniquity; and I will cause the arrogancy of the proud to cease, and will lay low the haughtiness of the terrible.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals God's purpose to humble the proud and punish wickedness universally.

keyVerses.text: And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the beauty of the Chaldees' excellency, shall be as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the total and irreversible destruction that will come upon Babylon.
